headline.main: Oscar, a New Health Insurer, Raises $30 Million

docs.abstract: Oscar, a health insurer co-founded by the venture capitalist Joshua Kushner, has raised $30 million in new capital from existing investors, the firm plans to disclose this week.
docs.snippet: Oscar, a health insurer co-founded by the venture capitalist Joshua Kushner, has raised $30 million in new capital from existing investors, the firm plans to disclose this week.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

headline.main: Responding to Readers on 'The House Edge'

docs.abstract: David Kocieniewski and Gretchen Morgenson answer questions about their series of articles examining the challenges posed by Wall Street’s influence over markets and the prices consumers pay.
docs.snippet: David Kocieniewski and Gretchen Morgenson answer questions about their series of articles examining the challenges posed by Wall Street’s influence over markets and the prices consumers pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks are higher on Wall Street, giving the Standard & Poor's 500 index its first up day of the new year.

headline.main: US Stocks Rise, Breaking a Three-Day Slump
headline.print_headline: US Stocks Rise, Breaking a Three-Day Slump

docs.lead_paragraph: Attorneys general from South Carolina and Florida have asked the White House to arrange a meeting with Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius over prosecutors' concerns about the health care overhaul.

headline.main: APNewsBreak: AGs to Obama: We Need Meeting on ACA
headline.print_headline: APNewsBreak: AGs to Obama: We Need Meeting on ACA

docs.snippet: Attorneys general from South Carolina and Florida have asked the White House to arrange a meeting with Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius over prosecutors' concerns about the health care overhaul.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee began running ads in 40 media markets Tuesday mostly targeting incumbent senators who supported President Barack Obama's health care program. Billionaire former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, meanwhile, gave $2.5 million to help Democrats defend their majority in the Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pharmaceutical companies including Switzerland's Novartis and Roche are among those developing a treatment for a specific type of lung cancer, a field that is now so crowded it may impact profits.

headline.main: Returns May Suffer as Drugmakers Compete in Crowded Cancer Field
headline.print_headline: Returns May Suffer as Drugmakers Compete in Crowded Cancer Field

docs.lead_paragraph: Efforts at modernizing the systems for government aid in many states have largely backfired in recent months, causing enormous cost overruns and delays for benefits.

headline.main: Faulty Websites Confront Needy in Search of Aid
headline.print_headline: Faulty Websites Confront Needy in Search of Aid

docs.abstract: Efforts at modernizing websites for unemployment compensation in many states have largely backfired, causing enormous cost overruns and delays for benefits; higher costs, botched systems and infuriating technical problems fall hardest on poor, jobless and neediest.
docs.snippet: Efforts at modernizing the systems for government aid in many states have largely backfired in recent months, causing enormous cost overruns and delays for benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: “Lifestyle” programs, which aim to reduce health risks via weight loss or stress management, resulted in no net savings, a RAND study says.

headline.main: Study Raises Questions for Employer Wellness Programs
headline.print_headline: Study Raises Questions for Employer Health Efforts

docs.abstract: RAND Corp study says so-called lifestyle management programs offered by companies to their employees, which aim to reduce health risks via weight loss or stress management, result in no net cost savings; study examined more than 67,000 people eligible to participate in PepsiCo's wellness program.
docs.snippet: “Lifestyle” programs, which aim to reduce health risks via weight loss or stress management, resulted in no net savings, a RAND study says.

docs.lead_paragraph: National health spending grew slowly in 2012, posting a relatively small increase for a fourth consecutive year.

headline.main: Another Modest Rise for Health Costs
headline.print_headline: Another Modest Rise for Health Costs

docs.abstract: Federal government says national health spending grew slowly for fourth consecutive year, increasing 3.7 percent in 2012 to $2.8 trillion; officials disagree over whether Affordable Care Act or lingering effects of recession were primarily responsible for trend.
docs.snippet: National health spending grew slowly in 2012, posting a relatively small increase for a fourth consecutive year.
